comments.commentBody:
According to Wikipedia, at least, the first university was chartered in the 1150's. That puts the earliest universities in the High Middle Ages, which are reckoned from 1000. The Dark Ages, if the phrase has a meaning today, are the Early Middle Ages, from the late 400's to 1000, called dark because of the relative paucity of primary sources (dark = unknown).

Read some history, D'Alien.

Before anyone says "pot, meet kettle" because I cited Wikipedia, I was looking for a date or two on which to anchor my claim that universities were a product of the High Middle Ages, before the thread closed. D'Alien's comment should really have been answered by a specialist in medieval history. What I'm protesting against is the facile, ill-informed claim that the entire span of time from 476 (when the last Roman emperor in the West died) to the beginning of the Renaissance was "dark," meaning shrouded in ignorance.

If philosophers were "in every corner on and off campus...to restore beliefs and values that led to the birth of universities" what beliefs and values would be appropriate with today's society? To my knowledge there is no definite right or wrong answer to a person's philosophy, it comes from ones perspective. You may have one idea that i completely disagree with but that does not make either of us wrong, so if philosophers were all around who has the right to determine what each philosopher should demonstrate? What standard would we hold these philosophers to or are they free to explain their own ideals of their philosophy? I do agree there needs to be more of a place for philosohy, but I feel that society is not ready to accept what current philosophers have to offer.

"Once knowledge and goodness were divorced, scientists could be regarded as experts, but there are no morals or lessons to be drawn from their work. Science derives its authority from impersonal structures and methods, not the superior character of the scientist. The individual scientist is no different from the average Joe; he or she has, as Shapin has written, “no special authority to pronounce on what ought to be done.” For many, science became a paycheck, and the scientist became a “de-moralized” tool enlisted in the service of power, bureaucracy and commerce." Naturally, professors are referred to as instructors, if not customer service reps, while students are consumers, customers, and fans. No wonder tribalistic college sports, not knowledge, seems the strongest "glue" and "unity" cohering the diverse academic units, creating a sense of self-worth and identity. I feel that we need philosophers in every corner on and off campus more than ever to restore the beliefs and values that led to the birth of universities in the first place during the Dark Ages.

The difference between the wealth in Hollywood and the wealth that supports the GOP is that the latter tends to be inherited. Therefore, the American conservative platform isn't necessarily grounded in principles of social mobility and self-reliance. Although, I suppose you could find exceptions in any era: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/02/20/elon-musk-spacex_n_2727312.html

I think that the real translation of your remarks, salahmaker, is that the money in Hollywood comes from the one-hit wonders while the money that gets inherited is money that has been earned and preserved over time.

So, the question becomes, which is more appropriate for the long-term sustenance of the economy?

Surely the Hollywood money is far more ephemeral and far less productive.
The post by "piece" is incoherent nonsense, words without meaning.

and as the specialist for 'Data' on this blog - I know that we firstly have to be successful in making the people understand that Obama has absolutely nothing to do with the things to come. It's all the doing of the Money Slosh - which (again) has jammed it's speculative tentacles into all the wrong places and now these places are slowly coming apart.
Or as the cynical gambler says: There will be great iinvestmennt' opportunities again - afterwards. But before afterwards there might be some disapointment and pain?

" Every jihadist in the world has seen those pictures and every one of them was thrilled to see our troops in such submissive photos."....Tim, the jihadists are Sunni. Iran is Shia. They have been at war with each other for about 1300 years. I know to some Americans the difference is a small point, but it is sort of important if you care to understand what is going on in the world.

Dan, you are obviously not one of those people who suffered a loss of income, or one of the states that had to pull together emergency funding to keep a national park and other revenue-generating federal programs "open".
Isn't this rich scofflaw the same Ted Cruz who advocates a regressive flat tax, further widening the gap between haves and have-nots?  Some people are just beyond shame.

@Dan: And when the government shuts down and then reopens some weeks later a few million staff members are paid their salaries retroactively- for work that they didn't get to perform.  Guess whose taxes are paying for that?
I hope you are right.

There was clear intent to deceive his base of supporters.
He knew very we'll that the Tea Party would not vote for a candidate that was being financed by Goldman Sachs or Citibank.
His phony narrative blew-up in his face.
True, jim, true.  I mean just the other day I forgot about this $200,000 I own for my kids college education.  Funny how those trivial 6 figure amounts slip your mind.
There's no smoke here. Most of us working folk know how easy it is to forget about a little half million dollar loan. Hey, he's human like the rest of us.
literally sleeping with them!
What a phony.  Runs a campaign criticizing Wall Street bailouts and big banks and is sleeping with them at the same time.   No surprise there.
There is nothing honest or transparent about Ted Cruz. Never has been; never will be. People who support him just don't know who he is.

What are the consequences of Mr. Cruz's "forgetfulness"? Does he face disbarment as a lawyer? A sanction from the Senate? An investigation into his ethics and other financial dealings? What are the consequences when someone purposefully defrauds the system? Against the large cash outlay of his opponent in the Texas race, his finances and the election results themselves look all the more suspicious.
deglaze skillet with vermouth and reduce for great gravy.

.
I can't either, besides "Bet It, Leigh!" (casino encouragement), which isn't especially rib-tickling, besides being derivative. It's their own fault for using alliteration. Magical Mystery Tour, Polythene Pam, Rocky Raccoon, Please Please Me, Sexy Sadie. It's kind of a shame, because "Sell! Oh, Yubmarine!", the cry of someone needing to raise funds at an auction, would be a spanner if it made a shred of sense.

I've had little success with album titles. Abbey Road is out because you need 2 consonants. "Subber Roll"? No. "Beat the ****les"? Won't pass standards.

Others I considered:
Juror for Lebowski? "Peer Dudence" [again, makes no sense]
Ache for Coach Wilkens? "Lennie Pain" [it's open to complaints about sports clues despite the fact that the man transcended his sport]
"Comoro Never Tows" or "Komoro Never Tows" would seem to me an unfair generalization about car mechanics in the named places. But again, 15 letters.

Thanks, NYT, for highlighting the real-time comments made by Ted and his presumably compliant wife:

“Sweetheart, I’d like us to liquidate our entire net worth, liquid net worth, and put it into the campaign,” he says he told his wife, Heidi, who readily agreed.

“What astonished me, then and now, was Heidi within 60 seconds said, ‘Absolutely,’ with no hesitation,” Mr. Cruz said.

So $750K of not very secured loans from Wall Street to the self-proclaimed man of the people aren't reported to FEC. And then the campaign claims these omissions were "inadvertent."

Inadvertent. That's rich. Show me a flying elephant, or a notarized statement by Dr. Seuss. Then I'll believe.

Or maybe not.
Yeah, what a woman!

What a sweet story! "Honey, let's liquidate everything, throw all our savings, all our-- what do they call it? liquidity?- into a crazy long-shot race for the Senate, even though I've NEVER run for elective office before, and the very conservative Lt. Governor, who has $24 million of his own funds to throw into the race, is seen as inevitable. I'll do the 'aw shucks' thing, be plain and humble (well, maybe not so humble), and run far, far to his right. Yeah, he's already way out there himself, but this is Texas, and I'll paint him as an effete, elite MODERATE. Maybe Goldman Sachs can help me out a bit." And she said YES! Heidi said YES! And the rest is history... unreported-on-financial-disclosure-forms history.
Her photography is amazing and insightful...It is not staged and catches moments of long ago reality.  She had the talent to choose subjects of continuing interest.

I see Cruz as exhibit A in support of Trump’s assertion that politicians are too beholding to special interests to serve the best interests of the public.

Goldman-Sachs was one of the companies that really worked to bring about the financial crisis. They were the ones who were pushing their clients into holding bad equity that they knew was bad, even as they staked out positions betting against their clients.

It is not surprising that Cruz is linked to them or that he would hide from the public a loan such as it is while claiming to be a populist. And his attacks against Trump for coming from NY city, really make no sense with Cruz’s close ties to NY’s Goldman-Sachs the epicenter of the ‘greed’ is good’ mantra.

Although one may blame the modern university as the cause of this "way-losing", I don't believe anyone has mentioned the handful of
large bulls which entered the china shop of philosophy about two centuries ago, namely:
* materialism--the belief that human thought and values are purely mechanistic phenomena--undercut any notion that people have
insight into reality, but only sense perceptions of it;
* radical relativism/subjectivism in support of radical individualism, which made it nearly impossible to talk about the actual truth or falsity of anything, PARTICULARLY anything which must be based on teleological concepts such as human nature;
* utilitarianism, which reduced things to the algebra of value propositions identical to the calculations done by insurance companies to set premiums; and
* and a cluster of closely related, highly reductive approaches which assess ideas not only by their content, but by the social group, ethnic background, skin color, and gender of the people expressing them.

These four areas, above, have driven philosophy away from its former roots, driven a wedge between it and common sense, and enthroned each individual as having the ultimate authority to define the truth to be whatever he needs it to be.

Proof of this last point can be seen in the comments on this article, in which there is a great variety of ideas about what philosophy actually is.

Tell that to the people that didn't receive social security payments during that time, or the 850,000 workers that were unexpectedly furloughed without pay. Call me crazy, but I have to believe you'd be upset if you were told you weren't going to get the opportunity to earn your paycheck for an indeterminate period of time thanks to the opinion of some C-suite director you've never met. Or any of the countless other duties you find trivial that our government performs. Maybe you should educate yourself on the true problems of a government shutdown before you speak https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2013/11/07/impacts-and-costs-government-...
Ted Cruz and Goldman Sachs? No big surprise. After all, sleazy is as sleazy does.
He is a liar, beholden to Wall Street!
Oops. Someone send the rescue team out to save Ted Cruz from his train wreck of a campaign.
Citibank was another of Cruz's lenders and they're not a charity either.

Bye Bye Ted.....this is exactly what makes the ordinary Joe hate politics and hate politicians. Lie, hide, always have an excuse.

No one is prepared or qualified for the Whitehouse.

Ted Cruz for president!? Why? and who will make this happen? corruption against the American tax payer.
Try the buttermilk in Melissa Clarksville recipe for buttermilk dressing with squash, arugula, radicchio, and walnuts. Yum

Made this tonight, using chicken pieces. Huge hit with the family. It soaked in the marinade for 2 full days and was moist and juicy and incredibly delicious.

I had buttermilk leftover from making the Green Goddess Roast Chicken, which everyone loved. They all liked this one even more.

Once the chicken was in the fridge and in the marinade, there was no work to be done, especially with the roaster lined in foil. Couldn't have been any easier.

Will be making again.
